# Question

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

```julia
function audi_filter(df_cars)
    # Filter DataFrame for Audi A4 and A4 Quattro
    filtered_df = df_cars[df_cars["manufacturer"] == "audi" && (df_cars["model"].match("a4|a4 quattro"))), :]

    # Create new column with true value for all rows
    filtered_df["audi_a4_type"] = true

    return filtered_df
end
```
This function `audi_filter` will filter the input DataFrame `df_cars` based on the conditions provided. It then creates a new column `audi_a4_type` with `true` values for all rows and returns the modified DataFrame.
